Pre-startup Safety Reviews 
Entergy will develop a procedure to conduct a pre-startup safety review for the new stationary sources or modified stationary sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in safety information under the management of change element.  This procedure will be developed for the startup of the SCR process.  The pre-startup safety review procedure will insure that procedures for safety, operating, maintenance, and emergencies are adequate and in place.

Mechanical Integrity  
Entergy will develop a program to assure the mechanical integrity of pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. 

Entergy will establish and will implement written procedures to maintain the integrity of process equipment.  Entergy's process maintenance personnel assigned to the SCR process will be trained on an overview of the process and its hazards. Offsite Consequence Analysis
Entergy performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release of ammonia to affect the public or the environment.  The OCA consists of evaluating both worst-case scenarios and alternative release scenarios. Entergy does not expect the events that would cause a worst case scenario to ever occur because of the nature of the process and the provisions for safe operation that are used by Entergy.  Alternative release scenarios help the LEPC improve the community response plan. 
 
Entergy has conducted an analysis of the potential impact of the storage of anhydrous ammonia at the Lewis Creek plant using procedures developed by the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency for Risk Management Plans.  

Entergy has evaluated a worst case scenario and an alternate case scenario as required by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for Risk Management Plans.  In this case, both scenarios have the potential to cause an off-site impact of public receptors.  In order to have a scenario with an off-site impact, a scenario was chosen that is still unlikely to actually occur but does potentially allow a release of ammonia that could impact public receptors outside of the plant property.  The more realisitic scenarios that might occur during the lifetime of the SCR process were evaluated and would not cause an off-site impact under normal weather conditions.  

The chances of a release that would impact any off-site receptors is further reduced considering the safety features of the process, the safe operating procedures, and the safety training of the operators of the process.  An ammonia release is also easily mitigated by use of a water spray from a fire hose over the point of release.  Use of on-site or local fire fighting equipment would greatly reduce the amount of ammonia leaving the plant, if an accidental release were to occur.  In addition, Entergy will have available a fo

Entergy has developed this Risk Management Plan to reduce the potential of accidental releases of ammonia by performing a hazard assessment, developing a prevention program, and conducting emergency response planning
 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
Entergy implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of a significant accidental release, our trained personnel respond to control and contain such releases as appropriate.  Each situation is evaluated individually  and appropriate measures are taken to protect the employees and the community.  (Entergy, the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and neighboring industries have established a program to warn the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.)  

Regulated Substances
Entergy handles several substances regulated by the RMP rule but ammonia is the only one present in sufficient quantities to be covered by the RMP rule.  The information below indicates the process as defined by the rule and the regulated substance.

Regulated Process:  This covered process consists of a storage tank containing a maximum of 150,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The liquefied ammonia is loaded into this tank from a tank truck/rail car.  This tank is supplied with redundant relief valves.  This operation is monitored by an unloading technician.  This ammonia is then transferred from the storage tank to the Selective Catalytic Reduction units on each boiler.

Five Year Accident History 
The five-year accident history includes all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.  Since this is a new process at the Lewis Creek plant, there is no accident history associated with the use of ammonia or any other chemical subject to the EPA Risk Management P

gging system to reduce the amount of ammonia escaping from any potential accident at the plant.  Entergy has determined that in most cases, the use of the fogging system will prevent concentrations of ammonia from exceeding EPA's end point concentration of 0.14 mg/l of ammonia.  EPA states that nearly all individuals could be exposed for one-half to one hour to concentrations of ammonia up to the 0.14 level without any serious health effects.  

The worst-case scenario is based on EPA's regulatory definition and not on any situation that is likely to actually occur at the facility.  EPA defines the worst-case scenario as the total release within 10 minutes of the largest single storage vessel of the regulated substance (ammonia) at the facility.  The weather conditions such as wind speed and atmospheric stability are also defined by EPA regulations for this scenario.  These are weather conditions that almost always cause the release to have the greatest impact possible for the site being studied.   The key to the analysis of off-site consequences is the concept of an endpoint.  The toxic endpoint for ammonia is 0.14 mg/L.  

The worst-case scenario was developed using an assumption of 150,000 pounds (approximately 28,500 gallons at 40 degrees F) of anhydrous ammonia released at 15,000 pounds per minute for over a period of 10 minutes, representing catastrophic failure of the storage tank.  The worst-case scenario assumes that no measures were employed to stop the release, and that the event happened on a warm, calm day without sufficient wind to disperse the released ammonia.  

Based on site-specific information applied to the EPA methods, the data indicates that a residential population of approximately 6,500 people (see footnote 1) would be in the area defined by the worst-case scenario.  A distance of 4.4 miles from the Lewis Creek Plant defines this area.  Public receptors such as schools, residences, hospitals, major commercial and industrial areas, and recr

eation areas are included in this area.  

The worst-case scenario gives Entergy information on the populations that should be included in any planning, communication, and public information efforts related to this project. 

Part of emergency planning is to also evaluate and plan for an event that, although still unlikely, would stand a greater chance of happening than the worst-case scenario presented on the preceding pages.  Consequently, Entergy has worked with the manufacturer of the ammonia storage equipment to prepare an alternate release scenario.  Entergy plans to install a fogging system to reduce the amount of ammonia leaving the area of the storage tank in case of an accidental release of ammonia.  Depending on the how the fogging system is used and the exact location of the release, the amount of ammonia escaping in an accidental release could be reduced from 40 to 90 per cent.  

An alternate release scenario is defined by EPA as a release that is more likely to occur than the worst case scenario and uses weather conditions that are more likely to occur in the area where the plant is located.  The main factors that control the size of the area impacted by the alternate release scenario are the weather conditions and the rate at which the material is released.  EPA suggests that the alternate scenario should include some off-site impact unless there is no scenario that causes an off-site impact.  

The alternate release scenario is based on accident release from the ammonia storage tank with more realistic weather conditions.  The alternate scenario assumes an accident that causes a small hole in the tank at or near where the fill line attaches to the tank.  A release rate of 4,830 pounds per minute was calculated based on a 2 square inch hole being caused by the accident.    If the fogging system was used the reduction in the amount of ammonia released caused by the fogging system could be close to 70 to 90 percent.  Using a 70 percent reduction, this

gives a release rate of 1449 lbs per minute.  This rate of release would not cause an off-site impact, so the use of a fogging system was not considered in the alternate scenario.  

There are very few realistic accidents that would cause the release of large amounts of ammonia from the process.  Most realistic accidents such as the opening of a pressure relief valve, or the failure of a line or connection would cause the release of only a small quantity of ammonia due to the automatic shutoff valves in the process.  These releases while they are more realistic scenarios, would not cause an off-site impact above the 0.14 mg/l EPA endpoint level. 

The release of a smaller amount than 3,000 pounds per minute would not cause any significant impact outside of the Entergy property.  The accident described using the fogging system could cause a concentration of ammonia of 0.14 mg/l at a distance of 0.3 miles from the Lewis Creek Plant which is within the plant property.  This scenario does not show any impact above the 0.14 mg/l level outside of the plant property.  The distance to the front gate of the plant from the units is around 0.4 miles.  The distance to any residential area is greater than 0.4 miles.   

In order to have an off-site concentrations of ammonia above the 0.14 mg/l level, the release would have to be at a rate greater than 3000 lbs per minute without any reduction from the fogging system.  The alternate scenario that was chosen is based on a rate of 4830 pounds per minute based on the 2 square inch hole in the ammonia tank.  At this rate, it would take just over 30 minutes to empty the tank.   This scenario would affect an area with an estimated population of approximately 70 to 80 people (see footnote 2).  A distance of 0.5 miles from the Lewis Creek Plant defines this area.  

The alternate scenario assumes that no measures were taken to stop the release and that the event happened on a warm day with average weather conditions for the area in which

the facility is located.  

The purpose of the alternate scenario is to allow the plant to discuss with the public and local officials including emergency response personnel a situation that is a more realistic accidental release than the worst-case scenario.  

Prevention Program Overview
The prevention programs developed by Entergy for the Lewis Creek plant includes a compilation of specific safety information, written operating procedures, and training of employees in those procedures.  The prevention program includes implementation of procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of the process equipment, for conducting internal compliance audits, and for investigation of every incident which results in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of ammonia.  The prevention program section of the RMP includes process safety information on the SCR process and specific information on ammonia.  This section of the RMP also discusses the employee training program for the Lewis Creek plant.  

The main prevention program component for the SCR processes is a comprehensive process hazard analysis (PHA), which consists of a rigorous, step-by-step examination of processes, equipment, and procedures to identify each point at which an accidental release could occur.   

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program SCR process at the Lewis Creek plant. Because the SCR process at the Lewis Creek plant that are regulated by  the EPA RMP rule are also subject to the Process Safety  Management (PSM) standard, this summary  addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system that will be in place to implement the accident prevention program once ammonia is present on-site. 

Process Safety Information
Entergy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and sp

ecific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific individuals in the plant are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information under the direction of the plant manager.  This information is available from the Plant Manager.

Process Hazard Analysis 
Entergy will conduct a process hazard analysis (PHA) for the SCR at the Lewis Creek plant process prior to startup.  The PHA will include the following items:

* Hazards of the process
* Identification of previous, potentially catastrophic incidents
* Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards
* Consequence of failure of controls
* Siting
* Human factors
* Qualitative evaluation of health and safety impacts of control failure

Entergy will review the results of the PHA as documented by the PHA review team.  Entergy will update the PHA every 5 years and will keep documentation of PHAs and actions for the life of the process.  

Operating Procedures
Entergy will prepare written operating procedures that give workers clear instruction for safely conducting activities involving SCR process.  In some cases, standardized procedures developed by industry groups or provided in industry-specific risk management program guidance will be used as the basis for an individual operating procedure.  Entergy will update the operating procedures whenever there is a major change in process and before startup of the changed process.

Entergy will develop operating procedures required by EPA under the Risk Management Plan for the SCR process.

Training
Entergy will develop a training program for its employees that are involved with the SCR process.    Information related to the training program will be available from the plant manager.  

There are several regulatory programs that have requirements for training that will affect the personnel who are involved with the new SCR process at the Lewis Creek plant.  

Training Requirements
Each employee

before being involved in operating a newly assigned process will be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures as specified in 40 CFR 68.69 Operating procedures. The training will include emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  The following parts of the operation procedures will be addressed by the training.  

(a) Operating procedures for the process including the following:

(1) Steps for each operating phase or after an emergency shutdown. 
(2) Operating limits  
(3) Safety and health considerations 
(4) Safety systems and their functions 
    
At least every three years, these employees will be provided refresher training. 

A method will be developed to determine that each operator has received and understood the training.  The method may be a test, a practical demonstration or simulation, and/or interview.  A record of the date of the training and the method used to verify that the training was understood by the employee will be kept by the facility.  These records will be available to an inspector during his inspection of the facility.  

Hazmat employee training will include the following:

(1) General awareness/familiarization training
(2) Function-specific training
(3) Safety training.
       (i) Emergency response information
(ii) Measures to protect the employee from the hazards associated with hazardous materials
       (iii) Methods and procedures for avoiding accidents 
       
A record of current training, inclusive of the preceding three years, in accordance with this section will be created and retained by Entergy for as long as that employee is employed by Entergy as a hazmat employee and for 90 days thereafter.

Entergy Lewis Creek Plant RMP Executive Summary

GENERAL
Entergy is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for Entergy workers, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, Entergy has established systems to ensure safe operation of the facility.  One part of this system is the Risk Management Program that complies with the Environmental Protection Agency's regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements.  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) describing the risk management program at Entergy's Lewis Creek plant.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMP requirements and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Entergy's Lewis Creek plant near Willis, Texas.

The Entergy Lewis Creek Plant is a fossil-fueled steam, electric generating facility burning natural gas and fuel oil.  The Lewis Creek Plant consists of two generating units with a combined capacity of 530,000 kilowatts.  Unit 1 initial operation was November 3, 1970 at 4:15 p.m., and Unit 2 initial operation was March 24, 1971 at 6:35 p.m.  Units 1 and 2 were designed to use natural gas as the primary fuel with No. 2 fuel oil as a standby.  The Lewis Creek Plant Standard Industry Classification (SIC) code is 4911.

The plant is located in Montgomery County, two miles west of Willis, Texas.  From Interstate 45-North, take Long St. Exit (No. 95).  Turn left on Longstreet Road and travel two miles to the Lewis Creek plant and enter through the main gate.  The area is rural with open pastures, rolling hills and forest areas.  Within 5 miles of the plant there are small subdivisions located on Lake Conroe and residential areas in the western side of Willis.  Immediately next to the plant is a reservoir that belongs to Entergy and has restrictions on public access.  

Texas LNG, a liquefied natural gas facil

ity, is located adjacent to and due north of the plant.  The power plant and the Texas LNG facility are the only industrial facilities in the immediate area.  

The burning of fuels such as natural gas or fuel oil causes the emission of nitrogen oxides.  Nitrogen oxide emissions from many sources combine with hydrocarbons in the air to form ozone.  The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has determined that by reducing the emission of nitrogen oxides in the Houston area, there will be a reduction in the ozone levels.  The TCEQ has required Entergy to install pollution controls at the Lewis Creek plant.  Based on this requirement, Entergy plans to install equipment called Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) units that will be used to reduce the nitrogen oxide emissions from the Lewis Creek plant's two boilers.  

Since, the SCR process uses ammonia, the Lewis Creek plant will become subject to the Federal Risk Management Program.  The Risk Management program is designed to promote safe operation of industrial processes.  The program is intended to protect the public and the environment.  Entergy is committed to protecting the safety of the public and its employees.  

At Entergy, our values are very simple. We believe there is only one way to do business: with fairness, honesty, and integrity. 
J. Wayne Leonard 

Values: 
Create and Sustain a Safe Work Environment
Our goal is to provide reliable quality service in a manner that preserves the safety of our employees, the general public, and the environment. Each of us has a responsibility to ensure that this goal is met. 

Entergy will have as a priority the safe use of ammonia at the plant.  Entergy is developing a program that will reduce the chance of an accidental release of ammonia.  This program includes the following:

1. Equipment and Processes designed for safe operation
2. Personnel trained in the safe use of ammonia and operation of the process
3. Cooperation with local officials including fire

and police departments, and 
4. Communication with local citizens

Entergy's commitment to the environment 
As one of the largest producers of electric power in the United States, Entergy recognizes the leadership role incumbent on a company of our stature and resources.  We are advocating public policy that will preserve and enhance the environment.  And we know that we can't play a leadership role on the environment if we don't walk the talk. 

Why ammonia is considered a toxic chemical?
Anhydrous ammonia (pure, undiluted ammonia) used for industrial purposes is a very powerful chemical compared to the diluted ammonia found in household cleaning products.  Ammonia is only dangerous to the public if it is released to the air, and even then it would have to be released in a large enough quantity to drift beyond the property line of the Lewis Creek Plant.  It is important to realize that the likelihood of a release of anhydrous ammonia is very slim and the release of quantities large enough to cause longer health effects is very unlikely.  Well-trained personnel using safe operating procedures at the Lewis Creek Plant will assure safe handling of the anhydrous ammonia.


Regulatory Programs
The Lewis Creek plant is subject to regulation by Federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Risk Management Program and by the Federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA).  Both of these agencies regulate the SCR process that will be installed at the Lewis Creek plant.  Entergy is designing the SCR process to have built-in safety features such as automatic shutoffs, flow controls, ammonia detectors, and other equipment that is designed to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  The personnel who operate the process will be trained in proper operation and how to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  Entergy will implement the procedures outlined in its Risk Management Plan (RMP) to assure that the public and the environment are protected.

recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices for inspection and testing.  

Entergy will correct equipment deficiencies found during inspections, tests, or by other methods before further use of the process equipment or whenever necessary to ensure safety and will establish a QA program for new construction and equipment, newly installed equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts and equipment.

Management of Change 
Entergy will develop procedures to address management of change.  The procedure will deal with the following issues:

* Technical basis for the change 
* Impact on safety and health
* Modifications to operating procedures
* Necessary time period for the change
* Authorization requirements for proposed change

The purpose of the management of change procedure is to assure that changes to the process, chemicals used, equipment, and maintenance or operating procedures are reviewed and approved prior to any changes being made.

Incident Investigation 
Entergy will develop procedures for the Lewis Creek plant to ensure that investigations of any incident related to the SCR process is initiated promptly.  Investigations will begin with 48 hours of an incident.  The procedures will include the process to establish a knowledgeable investigation team.  

The team will gather the facts, analyze the event, and develop the how and why of what went wrong.   At least one team member will have knowledge of the SCR process.  Entergy will consider adding workers in the process area where the incident occurred as part of the team.   The team will summarize the investigation in a report that  will identify the factors contributing to the incident.  Entergy will establish a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations.  Entergy will document the resolutions and corrective actions.  Entergy will review the report with its staff and contractors that are involved.

Compliance Audits 
Entergy will conduct an au

dit of the process to evaluate compliance with the prevention program requirements at least once every three years.  The audit will be conducted using an audit procedure developed by Entergy for the Lewis Creek plant.  The audit team will consist of personnel selected for their knowledge of the RMP requirements and knowledge of the process.  The team will consist of at least one person who is knowledgeable in the SCR process and will consist mostly of persons who are independent from the operations and environmental activities at the Lewis Creek plant.  

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Entergy has safety features on the SCR process to quickly detect a release, to contain or control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.

Emergency Response
Entergy has in place an Integrated Response Plan that describes, in one plan, all the emergency response actions required at the Lewis Creek plant.  The emergency response requirements under the Risk Management Program are being incorporated into the Integrated Response Plan.  Entergy will work with the local emergency response personnel to assure that everyone involved will be ready to respond when needed.   

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Since this is the first time that the Lewis Creek Plant has been subject to the RMP regulations, the facility will implement the prevention programs as outlined in the RMP and adhere to the RMP/Process Safety Management procedures.  Also, issues that are identified in the Process Hazard Analysis will be addressed with corrective action in a timely manner.
